Situation1: They check a routine prescription for a common cold and confirm the medication matches the label.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: I glanced at the clock above the pharmacy counter—6:45 p.m. The polls would close at 7, and I still had to rush home to grab my ID before heading to vote. My shift was supposed to end at 6:30, but a last-minute customer slid a prescription across the counter. It was for a common cold, nothing complicated, but I knew the expectation: double-check every detail, no matter how routine. My manager’s words echoed in my mind—accuracy above all else. I scanned the label, compared it to the prescription, and felt the pressure mounting. If I hurried, I might make it to the polling station in time, but if I rushed this check, I could make a mistake that would cost someone their health. My heart pounded as I weighed my duty to my patient against my right—and responsibility—to vote. The minutes ticked by, and I felt torn, caught between the white pharmacy lights and the distant promise of the ballot box, knowing I couldn’t fulfill both roles perfectly tonight.
